Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A major supplier has threatened to halt all future shipments until a significant past-due invoice is settled.
Story:
I stared at my phone, heart pounding. My girlfriend’s text glared at me: “I thought we agreed on Saturday, not Sunday. Why don’t you ever listen?” I could almost hear the frustration in her words. I knew I should call her, talk it out, smooth things over before it turned into something bigger. That’s what she expected from me—someone who cared enough to resolve things right away.

But just as I reached for the phone, my work email pinged. The subject line: “URGENT: Supplier Halting Shipments.” My stomach dropped. The supplier’s message was blunt—no payment, no more deliveries. I was the only one who could negotiate, explain the delay, and try to keep our business afloat. My boss expected me to handle this, and fast.

I sat frozen, phone in one hand, laptop in the other, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. My girlfriend needed reassurance and understanding. My company needed immediate action and clear communication. I could feel the tension building inside me, torn between the person I loved and the job that depended on me.
